subtitle: [Music]
Thinking Allowed.
Conversations on the leading edge of knowledge
and discovery with psychologist Jeffrey Mishlove.
Hello and welcome. I'm Jeffrey Mishlove. Today we'll
be exploring the history of remote viewing. With me is
Dr. Paul Smith, a philosopher, a remote viewer, author of
Reading the Enemy's Mind and The Essential
Guide to Remote Viewing, a founder and twice
president of the International Remote Viewing
Association. Welcome, Paul. Well, thank you for having me here. I really appreciate it.
I'm delighted to have you with me here in Albuquerque.
Thank you for making the trip. When we talk about
remote viewing these days there's a certain amount of
confusion because we're at a point now where there are,
I don't know, a dozen or more teachers of remote viewing
and different approaches. Some approaches are actually
antagonistic, mildly at least, to each other, and
certainly different, they are different
approaches. I think it would be very useful to review the
current status and the history of the field. And
certainly, you're very well-positioned to do that with me.
Thank you. Yeah, that would be... I know a lot of people get very confused.
There's all these different flavors of remote
viewing. It starts with TRV and CRV and SRV and
XRV and YRV and ZRV, right.
That confusion, if you know the actual genealogy of it, it
becomes unconfused and you can decide which one
of these you may be interested in following.
Well, let's start with this.
As a little bit of history with which I'm not yet really
familiar, how did you get recruited into the program?
Well, my conversion story to remote viewing, right,
convinced me that magic does happen.
If I remember you were a major in the Army. Yes.
Actually at that time, I was a captain.
I had just come back from an overseas tour
with the Special Forces and then went to the
career course for captains out in Arizona.
I was at Fort Meade working as
essentially an admin intelligence officer, sort of an analyst.
We were processing intelligence reports from the Middle East.
And I didn't know this but my military
quarters were right next door to Skip Atwater,
who was the operations and training officer,
and actually the founder of the Army program.
And, across the street from Tom McNair who was one of their most recent
remote viewers in training. So,
I got to know them. We had fun, all that kind of stuff. One day…
Just because of proximity… Yes. Well, the
proximity was the first miracle here, right. So,
it turned out that I was exactly what they were looking for.
So, fate or God or whatever, I don't know, put me in that
military quarters. How was it that you were what they were looking for? Well,
let me tell you how this unfolded. So Skip and Tom came over one day and they said,
“We think you might be good at what we do.” And I said,
“Well, what do you do?” And they said, “We can't tell you.”
I said, “Well, how do I know I want to do it?”
They said, “Well, here, we got some tests we're going to give you.”
They were pretty much standard psychology personality profile tests,
Myers-Briggs, MMPI, various ones like this. They said, “If you
score roughly where we think you're going to,
we'll read you on the program and then you can volunteer if you want to.”
Okay, so I took the tests. And here's what was going
on behind the scenes that I don't know about. So
there are guidelines that they got from the SRI
people, Hal Puthoff, Russell Targ and those guys.
The guidelines they got was, they were looking for
military intelligence officers that were well qualified in their skill set,
above-average intelligence, which despite what people
think describes most of the military intelligence core,
but an officer who had
side interests that were, or experiences that were, different than your
average officer. They involved some kind of creative experience. So,
studio art, painting or drawing or something like that.
Languages, which is a little more common in the intelligence
field but still maybe an involvement with foreign languages.
Music or
creative writing, some kind of creative pursuit. Well,
it turned out I kind of checked the box on all those.
I had majored in art and put myself through school as a botanical illustrator.
I'd been playing guitar for about twenty years by then. I like to write
fiction and send off and get it rejected by publishers. And
I was fluent in German and was competent in
Arabic and Hebrew. So, they knew all that about me
and they're drawing up this new training contract. They said,
“Well, we need to have people to plug into these slots.
Let's try Paul Smith.
”What year was that? This was 1983. Okay. The program
had been pretty well established at that point.
Yes. The Army had programming going on for about five years, five-ish years. And
of course, the overall program had been going on for eleven by that point.
So, okay, I apparently scored where they wanted me
to. They invited me over to the building where they
did all their work. These were old World War Two buildings that were left over.
They're supposed to be temporary and they were still there in 1983, what's that,
40 years, 40-50 years and they looked it as well.
I go back in the back and Tom sits me down and says, “Okay, well, here's what we do.
We collect intelligence against foreign threats using
a parapsychology discipline known as remote viewing.
We want to know if you'd be willing to volunteer to become a psychic spy.
But you don't have to tell me right now. We can give you 24
hours. You go home. These are the things you can tell your wife
and then you can tell us tomorrow.” I said, “I don't
need to. I want to do it.” And he looked kind of shocked.
I guess they've never had anybody actually volunteer that quickly.
What was happening was, when I was a kid I was interested in
science fiction that involved extrasensory perception and stuff.
Then I was in a junior high science project that involved the
Zener cards, you know, the wavy lines and the stars and all that stuff.
Total failure. No evidence of ESP whatsoever. So,
I at that point became a bit of a mild skeptic.
“Oh, you know, it'd be nice if it was true but it's not.”
As Tom is telling me this,
what's going through my head is this. I used to be
interested in this stuff. I thought it wasn't true.
They have appropriated money in the federal budget to train people how to do it.
And there's this ongoing program. That means it does
work. There is no way I'm not going to do this.”
And so, you know, it was just... I didn't even talk to my wife about it.
She was the kind to be very upset if I didn’t consult her about major changes.
But there was no negotiation on this one. I absolutely wanted to do it.
Then they put you through the CRV training program.
That's right. Now, we did other kinds of RV, too. I mean, our first experiences were
what's called extended remote viewing. I won't go into that right now...
Well, unless maybe I ought to go into it right now.
Well, let's just say this. We're talking about 1983.
We're talking about the remote viewing program at Fort Meade, run at that point by
Skip Atwater… And the Colonel, that was his boss. And
you were receiving training in more than one approach. Yes,
that's right. Right from the get-go. That's right. Okay, yes let's do. We've had
several discussions including previous ones with you and Lynn Buchanan on
CRV. So how do you distinguish extended
remote viewing from controlled remote viewing?
Okay. So, I said remote viewing is one of those XRVs that I was talking
about, because it's just yet another one on the menu of possible
remote viewing methodologies. So this is one that Skip actually developed
and it was a bit of a hybrid from the Monroe Institute
technology using sound
entrainment to alter brain states.
We did use those, what they call Hemi-Sync tapes,
they played different frequency beats in each ear
and it meets in the middle of your brain… It causes
what we call the binaural beat effect. Yes, that's right. So
they use those to get us into the mode in extended remote viewing. Now,
the most observable feature of ERV is that
the viewer is, in that case, laying on a bed.
I mean this was the only military job I ever
had where I actually got paid to take a nap.
It was great. You'd lay on the bed and you'd attempt to establish a
hypnagogic state, mind awake, body asleep condition.
And at some point, once you were in that mode,
you'd have a monitor come in or an interviewer,
they called it, for that particular modality.
The interviewer came in and he or she, although it was usually
Skip, would sit down at a desk that was in there, turn on a red lamp
so it wouldn't disturb you and be ready to
take notes. Then he’d just pose you questions.
First of all he'd give you the coordinate.
You'd go there and start describing what you experienced once you got to a location.
Then he would lead you through an investigation of that target location.
And then when you got done you got up and kind
of staggered out of the room and sat down at
another desk and made sketches and
comments about what you experienced, what you remembered from your experience.
You know, it's interesting that you mention the interviewer. Not long ago
I had a discussion with Russell Targ and I asked
him point-blank, how is it that the remote viewing
studies that were done at SRI were so very
successful, at least with certain percipients,
really outstanding, much better than most,
what we would call free response
clairvoyance and parapsychology back in the old days. And
he said, “It's the interviewer that makes the difference.”
That a good interviewer knows how to
elicit the psi mediated information and to distinguish
it from what we now call analytical overlay.
I would say Russell is partially correct in that. It’s very valuable to have an
interviewer, we call them monitors in the CRV methodology,
didn't perform exactly the same function but it kind of overlapped.
But the argument, the one thing to say in
opposition of that is that lots of good remote viewing
has been done solo, with just the viewer in the room. Now,
the interview is very helpful. Anytime I can have an
interviewer or a monitor working with me I much prefer that.
That individual performs a number of functions. Now you remember we're
talking double-blind here. That person doesn't know what the target is.
That’s right, absolutely. So in that setting
one of the big values that a
monitor/interviewer brings to the process is
to encourage you to keep going when you feel like you're ready to quit.
The temptation is to do less rather than more, it's kind of the
human laziness factor of it that factors into all of us, right.
Remote viewing can be a little
excruciating at times. If you get in and you're uncertain
whether you're even right or not and you're going
along and you'll say, okay, well I feel fairly comfortable about this,
I'm going to quit before I start feeling uncomfortable.
The monitor can encourage you to continue on. And very often
that's when the really good material starts to show up.
Another thing a monitor can do, or interviewer, either one, is...
Remote viewing
skews you a bit to your right brain, okay, to speak simplistically.
But it really is kind of, you start getting into this kind of ethereal sort of a mode.
First of all, your verbal skills start to kind of get a little sloppy and
your handwriting goes to heck if you're writing. It just becomes awful.
You're not necessarily thinking through the kinds of things that
you would need to report to satisfy whatever the requirement is
because you're just going stream-of-consciousness.
Well, the monitor can be over there saying, “Okay
you've talked about this and this and this.
Can you elaborate on those things rather than the
flower you just discovered over here to the side.”
Because remote viewers do get distracted by things
that appear to be more interesting to them, right.
A monitor or an interviewer, a good one,
can help bring you back to the task at hand.
So both extended remote viewing and controlled remote viewing
use the interviewer or monitors. Yes, in the classical case.
Now, there's plenty of people who do them solo,
particularly today. But although ERV is harder
to do solo… ERV, extended remote viewing.
Now, I still don't know the difference between ERV and
CRV. So, in ERV… Here's the most obvious difference. In ERV
the viewer is laying on his or her back or in a comfortable setting
trying to get as close to sleep as possible without going to sleep.
In a CRV session
you’re sitting at a desk with paper and pen and
you start off fully awake and fully conscious.
Now, the process induces a sort of mild altered state
of consciousness. By the time you get to the end
— there's a technical term in remote viewing, we say you get dingy —
so by the time you get to the end in a good CRV
session you're kind of a bit loosey goosey too
but you start off fully conscious and
you're recording information as you go. As opposed to
ERV where you can only do it at the end when you kind of
come out of it and have to do it by memory. Okay, yeah. So
we see that these two approaches develop pretty early on.
CRV developed by Ingo Swann. ERV developed by Skip Atwater. Yes.
On the CRV I want to quaff it a little bit. Ingo was probably the major developer
but he had a lot of interaction with Hal Puthoff. Ingo
insisted that Hal get credit for playing a major role in the development of CRV.
Hal does acknowledge that.
Yeah, they really worked as a team but Ingo was the most prominent figure in that.
Well,
since we're talking about the history of remote viewing and I did mention
what used to be called, and some people probably still use the term, free response
clairvoyance as opposed to the Zener cards, that would be forced choice
clairvoyance. You have only five choices. You have to make one of them.
Free response means whatever pops into your head you report it.
It can be anything, yeah.
That goes back a long way in the history of parapsychology.
Yeah, although
there are a lot of different tangents that all kind of came
together with remote viewing. So, clairvoyance in general,
although it may be splitting hairs, the distinguishing feature between the two is
clairvoyance implies only visual, right, and
it comes from the French for “clear seeing.”
So, implies only visual. Remote viewing is, even though the term remote viewing also
implies only visual, I think it's a misnomer.
It should have been “remote perception.”
After the program was shut down Ingo and I could
talk freely about all this stuff over the phone.
I got in arguments with him about the term remote viewing versus remote perception.
I truly believe today it should have been called remote perception
but, you know, we've now got this installed basem everybody
calls it remote viewing. That's really hard to change.
Sure, but I think most people understand that viewing
is kind of a generic word that means any form of
psi related input. Well,
it's surprising how many people don't
realize that. At least in the field they do.
The people who are coming into the field because
of remote viewing really truly expect it to be a
mostly visual experience. But in fact in remote viewing all the
sensory experiences involved. Now, your senses aren't involved
but it is the sensory experience because the
perceptual centers in the brain that the senses normally
stimulate are stimulated by this external input.
And so it's as if you are having a visual experience, as if you are smelling smells,
it's as if you are feeling, you know, having the tactile experience.
Whereas clairvoyance, really none of those extra
elements are usually emphasized or even thought about.
So that's
probably one of the biggest differences between remote viewing and
clairvoyance is that remote viewing uses a cocktail of perceptual experiences.
Clairvoyance tends to be considered a kind of a unidimensional one.
So I suppose we could point to people like Renee Warcollier in
France who published a book about his free response clairvoyance experiments.
Upton Sinclair, the famous American writer who
had many bestsellers going back to the 1930s,
wrote a book called Mental Radio. He even had
Albert Einstein write… Wrote the forward to it.
Forward to it, I think one edition of that book.
Yeah.
And interestingly, Ingo Swann, in his development
of all of this really was careful to acknowledge his
inspirations. He
freely essentially praised Renee Warcollier and Upton
Sinclair for the work they did, and Harold Sherman
was someone else that he really gained valuable insights
and things from as he’s creating remote viewing.
The interesting thing though, the kind of conceptual difference between Warcollier
and Sinclair and remote viewing is that remote viewing does have this sort of
clairvoyant notion. That is, that you are in
some way projecting your consciousness —
and I'm speaking very loosely here because we don't know really what's going on, right
— but you're projecting your consciousness out to a distant target
or an occluded target, a target that's hidden in some way. What
Warcollier and Sinclair both thought was going on with them was a telepathy thing,
that it was one mind to another, it was a sending
and receiving of thoughts. Mind to mind.
Harold Sherman as well in Thoughts Through Space, his
book title, and also implies mind to mind. Yes.
And while, you know, you can argue that maybe
they were telepathy experiments I think that
there's a stronger argument to suggest they
were actually proto remote viewing experiments.
They were proto... Well, they involved more clairvoyance
more likely than mind to mind communication.
Well, the truth is we have a lot of different terms in the field but what
we lack is a good theoretical understanding of how this actually occurs.
Yeah. It's interesting and I often get the question, “Well, how does this work?” And
I'll say, there's two different ways to answer that.
The first way is I can tell you everything you do to make
it make it happen. So I'm telling you how it works, right.
But the question you're asking isn't that.
The question you're asking is — you're standing in for my questioner, right —
the question you're asking is what is the causal
mechanism that brings remote viewing to be successful.
And that we don't have an answer for.
Speculation about it, but we don't have an answer.
In fact, the question itself implies that this
is a phenomenon that has a causal mechanism. Yes.
Well, in fact it obviously has to have a causal mechanism
but whether it's any kind of causation that we understand
or have ever encountered other than in this kind of
intuitive way, we don't even have an answer to that question.
Well, my best guess is that we need to pay attention
to what mystics throughout history have been saying
which is that there is a level of consciousness
at which we are one with everything.
That's my view. These days
I'm settling in on that,
that somewhere deep within you you are one with the entire universe.
But how you have the ability to find a particular...
See, you just pushed the “how does it work question” back another level.
That's all you've done
by saying that. But let's keep our focus now on the history because
even before you were invited to join this program at Fort Meade
there was quite a lot of history that took place.
There was a research center set up in California at SRI International,
a big military industrial think tank.
Of course, I've had many interviews with Ed May
and Russell Targ about that end of the program.
Then somewhere along the line the military decided they
didn't want to only rely on these California scientists,
they wanted to have their own independent unit
that would be really under military control,
not under control of civilians. Yeah.
The desire there actually was, you had the research arm out in California
and they did a little bit of operational work.
Now, when I say operational I mean like real world, boots
on the ground kind of intelligence collection, right.
So they did a little bit of operational work at SRI
but their main mission was to research the phenomenon. Military
realized there's some real usefulness to this thing,
we want to be able to try, you know, we want to turn in
a crescent wrench and start turning bolts with it, right.
So that's why these programs became generated.
Now, of course there was also the below the threshold agendas,
the people involved with these were really fascinated by the whole idea
and they wanted to see what they could do with it.
The general that got it started in the Army, Major General Ed Thompson...
Now, of course generals don't get down and do all this work.
It came to his attention that Skip Atwater — in fact then he was known as Fred,
Fred Holmes, Atwater is his legal name, right. Skip
Atwater had an interest in this from a counterintelligence perspective.
You'll have
to get Skip on sometime, but he had a very interesting path that brought him to this.
General Thompson became aware that Skip was interested,
so directly, he actually reached down through all
those echelons and ordered a second lieutenant —
Skip might have been a first lieutenant,
he was a lieutenant —
he ordered a lieutenant to create this program.
And that's very rare that a general will get down there like that and do that.
But that gave of course Skip the blessing of really the
highest ranking officer in the Army intelligence world
to actually do something here.
That was where the Army program came from.
Now, the Air Force had had an informal program
earlier under a gentleman named Dale Graff
who really doesn't get the attention he should in his contributions to this field.
But Dale ran a program there for a while
until he went over to the Defense Intelligence
Agency. He was at Wright-Patterson Air Force base.
Wright-Patterson, working for the Air Force,
yeah.
And as I recall from our earlier conversation
he didn't really have a formal unit
but he was sort of working independently and a little bit informally.
Yeah. Now, he did have the sanction of his superiors to do this
but there was no line item in the budget to manage this program,
it was sort of just out of hide as they say,
you know, and had a few folks, Air Force enlisted
folks who were interested in the program,
or interested in the thing. He invited them in
and that was sort of a part time thing they did.
Quite independent of Skip Atwater. Yes.
Now, you mentioned General Thompson as being a key figure.
How did he get involved?
Well, I don't know exactly all the background
from him but he did know about the program.
He got briefed. My recollection is he might even have
gone out to SRI to get a full briefing on the program.
He's one of those folks that, this is pretty
darn cool, let's see what we can do with it.
What was his position within the Army at the time?
At the time he was what they call the Assistant
Chief of Staff for Intelligence in the Army.
So he was the senior Army staff officer over intelligence
and you really didn't get more senior than that
in the Army in terms of power and position.
And since he became interested in it he was
able to make this, at least get this started.
Because I've always associated the program largely with General Stubblebine.
Yeah, Stubblebine came along later.
But he was actually a great asset. He was an asset and a detriment to it, right.
He was an asset in the sense that he saved the program from being terminated.
Stubblebine.
Stubblebine did, yeah. I don’t remember all the
details but Perry who was later Defense Secretary
was a chief of staff of the DoD, or not chief of
staff, assistant deputy or something in the DoD
and he issued a memorandum that said that no Army
research funds could be used for this kind of research.
And that was what they were living off of.
If you terminate the funding then the program goes away
and that was his goal. William Perry, was his first name.
That was his goal. He wanted to get rid of the program.
But Stubblebine kind of thumbed his nose at him and said,
all right then. I'm gonna pay for it out of the Intelligence Security Commands,
that was his command, the Intelligence Security Command.
I'm gonna pay for it out of my budget,
you know, just pull it out of hide again, took it away from...
You know, they all have discretionary funds in these commands
and they need them for unexpected contingencies
and he just said, I'm gonna pay for this.
And so for two or three years that's how we got funded,
money out of the Ins Comm budget directly without it being an appropriated
line item. So,
it sounds like at the higher echelons within the Army there was some controversy.
Yes. Well, it's one of the many interesting pieces of the saga is
that you had people who are absolutely adamant supporters of this
and they were in position to help make sure it stayed alive.
You had people who were absolute adamant detractors,
did not want to have it, didn't feel like the Army should be in it,
didn't believe in it, felt threatened by it, whatever.
They all had different kinds of motivations who were doing their best to kill it.
And so it was on this kind of rocky landscape for quite a while,
in fact forever.
It was always the issue.
But of course many federal programs are like that
because you have to every year go back and justify the money that is being spent on it
and make sure Congress appropriates the amount of money that you need
and usually they don't appropriate enough and then you got…
You know, it was a tangled mess of bureaucracy
in addition to all this excitement we were doing...
But I gather at some point the funding actually
was directly appropriated but from Congress.
Yes. What happened was,
here's the curse that Stubblebine brought.
He got a little too in love with this stuff
and started doing kind of wacky things.
There were a couple of semi scandals that happened under his watch
and the Army hierarchy said
this is just making the Army look bad,
we've got to do something about this.
So they essentially forced Stubblebine to retire
and they brought in actually formerly an artillery officer
who had been rebranched into military intelligence,
and brought him in to clean house.
So he came in and his first instinct…
Can you tell me who that was?
Yeah, that was General Soyster.
I know his first name too but it’s not coming to me right now.
Soyster came in and they had essentially told him,
do something about this.
So he was going to terminate the program.
But what they didn't realize, the ones that wanted to get rid of the program,
is that there was enough Congressional and Senatorial interest in the program
and in the higher echelons of the intelligence community,
interest in it, that they couldn't kill it.
But they could find another home for it.
So they ended up sending us all, lock stock and barrel, off
to the Defense Intelligence Agency.
Now, the way it works is you have the Army and the Air Force,
these services with their intelligence services.
DI is one echelon up.
So Defense Intelligence Agency supervises the intelligence world
for the services.
And so, it can tell these guys what to do,
these guys can't tell it what to do, okay.
So that was a good home for it.
And so we ended up there for several years
actually until the program was terminated.
How long were you in the program?
I was there from August of 1983 to August of 1990,
so a total of seven years. And during that time I imagine
you witnessed quite a bit of evolution.
Yes, a fair amount of turmoil. Evolution
in terms of refining the process,
evolution in terms of getting some really awesome results,
some really amazing results.
And then of course there were the results that didn't work.
That's one thing about remote viewing
is that sometimes it works and sometimes it doesn't.
The times when it works well is very obvious that it worked
and it’s very obvious there is only one explanation
that it involves some kind of extrasensory perception.
When it doesn't work you have no idea why it didn't work. Okay, and
along the way various modifications of the basic protocol were developed.
Yeah. So, let's go back to the post extended remote viewing days. We
always used extended remote viewing throughout the life of the program
but controlled remote viewing was introduced between ‘82 and ‘84, ‘85.
So what happened was Stubblebine wanted to be able to train
your average soldier to do this stuff.
But most of what they'd worked with is people
that showed some kind of psychic ability
and they weren't trained, they were kind of found.
Now, what was observed at SRI was that the more they did it
the more consistent their results were and the
more often they were on the signal line, right.
People improved over time.
Well, they at least improved in reliability
because sometimes the very first or second
remote viewing work somebody did was just amazing
and then it kind of fell off from there. And then they brought it back up. I
mean, it would be very hard to improve on the absolute best remote viewing
so that we're done.
But where you improved was in doing that kind of work more often. Consistency.
Yes.
And of course, the other part of it is taking somebody who doesn't know anything
about how to do it,
and that's where the training comes in, and
bringing them up to the point where hopefully
they reach that kind of consistency or at least improve their abilities.
I mean, in your case, though you had an
earlier interest in ESP, you were skeptical.
You didn't consider yourself a person who could exhibit ESP when you started.
To that point, I had nothing that could even
be identified as a psychic experience. Nothing.
And I never heard the two words “remote viewing” together.
I was totally naive about all this.
I had no idea any of this existed
so I was about as close to a blank slate as you could get coming to the program.
And so you would be an example of a person who was trained to do it.
Yes, absolutely, which brings back to where I was. So,
in order to satisfy Stumblebine’s desire to come up with a training program,
Ingo and Hal started working on this.
The point of what they're trying to
identify, what had worked for remote viewers
up to that point, what had proven successful, what had proven not successful,
and then with that as their foundation, they
had to then experiment with all kinds of
different ways of approaching it
and essentially as a trial and error, brute force kind of research effort.
They did thousands of remote viewing sessions, Hal and Ingo together.
They would take notes on what had worked that time and what didn’t.
Now, sometimes something will work one time and not another, then another time.
So they had to keep track of that too, right.
Literally thousands?
Yes, literally thousands.
Now, that I didn't know. Yeah,
they sort of started on this in the late 70s.
Stubblebine didn't come on the scene until
about ‘81 but that's when it became a prominent effort.
But they had in the meantime been researching all this stuff.
They had been exposed to subliminal perception
research to the split brain research, all
of which plays a role.
Not necessarily the ESP part, because
nine-tenths of this is the perception psychology part,
because human psychology is probably the biggest obstacle to doing this well.
So they had been focusing on both sides of
this, both the whatever that signal is coming
in and how to perceive it and then all the processing and the management that goes on
inside the person's head as they're trying to decode that signal.
So they were working on all that stuff and over time they came up with this currently
six stage process where you first learn just to get the general first impressions,
we called it gestalt. Gestalt of the target,
is it land, is it water, structure,
you know, just the nature of it.
And then you get into sensory experience where you get the smell, sounds, tastes...
Smells, sounds, tastes, visuals like colors and quality of light and...
Tactile. Yes, thank you, yeah.
You get those things come in, there's a basket of sensory experience
and then you get into the next stage. Stage three is where you start to make sketches
and you start to bring the dimensionality of it together in your mind.
So let me use an example. I use the Eiffel Tower as an example because I don't
use it as a target. None of my students will ever get the Eiffel
Tower as a target so I'm free to use it as an example.
So, let's say the target is the Eiffel Tower,
it's a training target because that's what
you'd use that Eiffel Tower for, it wouldn't be an operational target.
You want the viewer to describe the Eiffel Tower.
The first thing to know is that the viewer cannot know what the target is,
consciously is not allowed to know what the target is.
And if you're in an operational or experimental
research session you don't want the monitor
to know what the target is either. You want it to be double-blind.
So what happens is the viewer starts out blind to the target and then starts to…
Some other time we'll talk about how you
get them to recognize where they need to go.
Well, we've already done two interviews on the training process.
Okay, I can’t remember what I said.
Yeah, we did. We have the initial stages and then a
second interview on the advanced stages, so we don't
need to repeat that now
but what I'm really interested in is…
So then I'll put that on pause there. But go ahead
and ask me your question because I may be going
where you want me to go
anyway. Well, I mean the program closed officially,
as far as we know, as far as I know, around
1996. It was ‘95. It was closed on June 30th 1995.
And subsequently many of the people who were
involved in the program began moving into
the private sector and setting up, such as you have done.
You have a company called Remote Viewing Instructional Services.
I think I forgot to mention that in my introduction… That’s
fine. That’s good product placement… Happy to mention it now.
But you are among, let's say, a dozen other people who were through the program at Fort
Meade or had something to do with the research at SRI…
Who sort of went public. Yeah.
Or worked with Dale Graff in the Air Force.
I don't know how many other people were influenced
because, let's face it, books were being
written. We're at a point in time in history
now where it's fair to assume that I'm gonna
say that millions of people are now familiar
with the term remote viewing, have read books,
have watched videos, have gone through training programs.
There are many different approaches that
emerged out of it. Today there's almost like a
supermarket of courses you could take.
Yeah, smorgasbord.
Yes, smorgasbord might be the right word.
Most people don't know what that means anymore, but a buffet, let's say.
Yeah okay. So let's do kind of cut to the chase here.
That's a good point.
So, when the program was shut down there were
really three methodologies being practiced there.
One was CRV, and I've just talked about that.
The other was ERV, or extended remote viewing.
That was done relatively rarely but it was still done.
There was another methodology called WRV, for written remote viewing.
That one was even within the office kind of controversial because it involved something
that was similar to a kind of a blend of automatic writing and channeling.
The people in charge, including Dale Graff,
were okay with it because they said, it doesn't
matter how you do it,
if you're getting real data do it that way.
Back then we were a little worried about
that because we didn't want to be associated
with channeling or any that kind of stuff right.
But today I kind of see their point and that's sort of my attitude too.
If it works, don't mess with it,
even if it's not the kind of thing you do, then
go ahead. And if you're producing legitimate
results, you know, high quality to legitimate
results, because some of these methodologies produce
just mediocre kinds of results.
But, to be producing high quality legitimate
results, who cares what you call it or
how you do it.
Well, there's the sociology of the phenomena.
That's a side thing, yeah,
that’s a side thing.
In terms of just practical use it doesn't matter.
In terms of social acceptance or acceptance by mainstream science or whatever, then you
have to start thinking about image…
Or even critics of the program, who say, “Oh, they're bringing in witches.”
Yes, that was a problem. Yes, that's right. That's an unsavory element that
entered in and people started name calling.
Anyway, so those are the three methodologies.
Well, long after the declassification... Well,
it wasn't long down the declassification.
It was about four months later on Nightline,
Ted Koppel, his whole program was dedicated
to this weird psychic spy program that the military
had just just closed down and declassified.
He had Ed May on there. He had a customs agent who had actually used remote viewing.
He had Joe McMoneagle. Dale was on there. Oh, and... Keith Harary as I recall.
I don't remember him, maybe he was. I don't remember him.
But also Gates, not Bill Gates... Robert Gates who at one time was the
CIA... Well, later he was the CIA Chief, he was going to be Secretary of Defense.
He'd been at least in the upper echelons of the intelligence world for a long time.
He was somewhat hostile to the program.
Yes. He said at no time was this ever used to determine policy, which is a little bit
misleading because very little intelligence has ever been used to determine “policy,”
because policy is a fairly complicated…. Formulation
of policy is a fairly complicated high order level of
thing in which a whole bunch of ingredients go
into. Remote viewing was used tactically and
strategically on the ground successfully.
He never said that. It didn't have to do with policy, it had to do
with solving problems.
So anyway, Koppel has this on and the world goes nuts.
There's like dozens and dozens of newspaper articles. Right about the same time
as when… This was really the first major public
revelation, although there had been other...
Well yeah, Jack Anderson, who... I actually married his managing editor…
Yes, we talked about that previously.
He had been publishing stuff, it was garble.
I mean, he couldn't get the clear story but
he was trying really hard.
So, it had come out but this was the first
full official acknowledgement that it existed.
I suppose you could say there were rumors prior to that time.
Rumors that most people had never heard.
And books. I mean, Puthoff and Targ published Mind Reach back in the 1970s.
Which carefully avoided any acknowledgement of the military.
No, but they published a lot of data about remote viewing.
Yes. There had been articles in journals and stuff. McMoneagle even published his
book in ‘93, his first book. He also avoided
any connection with the military, he associated
it all with the Monroe Institute.
So, this is the first official, “Real, yeah,
everybody knows this is real now” stuff.
The newspapers picked it up. There were two phenomena that were happening
in the social world.
One was late night paranormal radio shows,
most notably Art Bell and his Coast-to-Coast show.
The other one was the world wide web.
Both of those things happen at the same time that this program was revealed and it
got picked up in those two venues and went crazy, literally went crazy.
Remote viewing is really what made Art Bell really big.
He got Ed Dames on there… As a frequent guest. Who
was a frequent guest with lots of wild stories.
Yes. Let's talk about Ed Dames for a moment.
People, many people won't know who he is.
What was his role at the Fort Meade program?
So, Ed had been a consumer of our products in
a sister unit that didn't do remote viewing,
did regular intelligence collection.
In other words, he created various tasks for the Fort Meade unit.
That's right.
He made requests and we tried to fulfill them, right.
He was fascinated by this.
He really really really really really really wanted to be in it,
but he couldn't get in because he was in the
wrong chain of command and the people at Fort
Meade were a little leery of him because he
tended to be a little over enthusiastic about some things.
Ultimately, he got his unit to sponsor him and get included on the training contract.
So, when we were going to SSRI to get trained
in CRV he got to come along and be one of
the four of us who were trained by Ingo.
He got up through stage three and then the contract ended and he went back to his unit
and we didn't see him again officially, didn't see him again for two years.
Then when the program was transferred to DIA,
they brought Ed Dames in to be a monitor and
the project manager.
He was not brought in to be a remote viewer.
They specifically wanted him in those kinds of administrative roles.
So he was doing that and then he got involved
in the training and he ultimately didn't do
a lot of remote viewing in the unit.
I counted nine sessions that he did and most of us did over a thousand.
But he became very well known later on because
he set up a company for the purpose of training,
one of the very first businesses.
Yes. He started Psi Tech, and he was at the time, he'd retired and had moved to
New Mexico. I created the first Psi Tech logo for him.
I was playing around with desktop publishing and I created it. It involved
the New Mexico sun logo with an eye in it.
I was actually there for the founding of Psi Tech.
It was in his house. It was before he moved to New Mexico, before he even retired
from the Army, in a little town of Maryland near Fort Meade.
So he brought together a lot of the people involved.
As I recall my friend John Alexander was on his board.
Was on his board.
Stubblebine was on his board.
He got letters of endorsement from Ingo Swan.
I and Lynn Buchanan and Mel Riley and some
other folks worked as viewers for him.
This was 1989,
so this was before he even retired.
So what he was doing was probably technically illegal
but the Army wasn't paying attention to this back then.
So he went on, retired, went out to Mexico.
And then, before the thing was declassified he started talking about it.
That may have been one of the things that led
to the declassification, was Ed and another
one of our folks there, Dave Morehouse, started
talking about it in public and making claims
and all kinds of stuff.
There are reports in the Stargate Archives that
the CIA declassified with people saying, “You
won't believe what Ed Dames did.”
But Dave, what's interesting about him is he really was very sensational.
He got a lot of people's attention about remote viewing.
So the upside of Ed Dames was he brought a lot of people to the field.
The downside is that he didn't just stop at what was true.
He went way beyond what was true.
So, a lot of these people came in with misconceptions about what
remote viewing really was. And plus it alienated
a lot of the mainstream scientists who might
otherwise have been interested. Yeah.
As I recall at that time there were claims being
made about a hundred percent accuracy and “military
grade remote viewing.”
And of course also they began offering
training programs that were rather high-priced. Yeah.
Well, mine are high priced too so I won’t quibble with that.
Well, actually maybe we ought to talk about that at some point.
But yeah, he was offering these training
programs and he went with a new terminology,
which he called TRV for “Technical Remote Viewing.”
He'd taken the old Army protocol and methodology
and he recreated, he added and enhanced stuff
and this new thing called Technical Remote Viewing.
So he put his own twist on it. Yeah.
Well, the interesting thing was at first he
was just passing out the same old Army manual.
So if he had changed it, it must've been only a name change.
So there was an Army manual? Yes.
Well, I'm sorry I said Army, but it was DIA.
I wrote it. Well, I edited it.
I didn't know that there actually was a manual.
Yeah. It's called the Coordinate Remote Viewing
Manual, May 1985, and it's about that thick.
So CRV could mean Coordinate Remote Viewing or Controlled Remote Viewing.
It refers to the same thing.
Originally Ingo wanted to call it Controlled
Remote Viewing but they call it Coordinate
Remote Viewing instead because originally they were targeting you with the geographic
coordinate. They wanted to do that because they felt like the military understood that
a little better. They understand coordinates better than…
Like targeting artillery or something. Yes, exactly. But
once it got declassified and there was more flexibility Ingo made a public request
that it be called Controlled Remote Viewing and so all of us call it that from now on.
Frankly it is a better term because we don't actually use latitude/longitude
anymore to target viewers. The control refers to the fact that you're essentially
establishing some control over this process instead of just letting it be a lazy affair
ad hoc, whatever happens kind of thing.
You actually are imposing some discipline on it to help direct it to what you need to
do. So it's really a good term for it. Okay. So how did TRV differ from CRV?
Well, when it first started it was identical.
There
was just a different cover on the manual.
Then
as time went on Ed wanted to then create it as a product
so you could put it on videotape, make it a home study kind of a course.
He was of course in the frontier on that kind of thing as well.
Now there are quite a few different home-study courses available.
Yes, there are. I even have one. So
he wanted to do that
but the actual methodology is designed for
live training, for training people in person,
and that's when it is actually the most effective in my experience.
Well, because you get feedback and more of a personal relationship....
Yes, you can get your questions answered instantly.
There's more encouragement.
There's lots of ways why that's better.
But he wanted to be able to mass market
and so it was going to go on video.
So he started simplifying.
He created a…
Not a format, a template,
templates to do things on
which, yes, it made it easier to present in a mass media kind of a format.
But the problem is it also tended to restrict the process
and I think add boundaries to it that made it less efficacious in my opinion.
That continued until today.
Really what he teaches — he doesn't even call
it TRV anymore because he lost the rights
to it in a court fight a while back.
So does Psi Tech still exist?
It does but he has nothing to do with it.
His former girlfriend and her then-husband sued him and got the rights to Psi Tech and
to everything associated with it including the TRV name. So
he had to go out and kind of reinvent what he was doing again.
So what he does now, as near as I can tell,
has only a faint resemblance to the original
CRV.
I don't think he has a name for what he does currently.
I could be wrong about that, but I don't think he does.
Now, the interesting thing is of course, that accounts for one name change,
CRV to TRV which started not being much
different but then morphed away from the CRV.
He had another student named Courtney Brown who
came in 1993 before any of this got revealed
and spent 13 days, 12 or 13 days with Ed and got trained by him.
He was a professor.
He's still a professor at Emory University in political science, his field.
He came and he had…. He'd spent 20 years in transcendental meditation
and he also had as much of a fascination with
UFOs and extraterrestrials as Ed Dames did.
So he wrote a book after that, published a book in which he tied remote viewing very
deeply into the UFO/ET kind of a thing.
He generally created his own methodology which he called SRV for Scientific Remote
Viewing. If you go on his website, which is Farsight.com I think.
The Farsight Institute. Yes,
he has free courses in SRV.
Now the difference there is that he took TRV, which is already a derivation of CRV,
and derived it further and injected... I'm
not an expert on TM but I think I see elements
of transcendental meditation involved in it,
and added some metaphysical kinds of elements.
Well, one thing is kind of science fictiony of subspace,
he had subspace, which I find very dubious myself because nobody knows what the
heck that is,
nobody's ever shown that it exists,
but he's added that in, kind of a Star Trekian kind of thing
and other elements that he's borrowed.
And then he comes up with a Scientific Remote Viewing.
Well, I'm not sure how scientific it is but it is an approach and some people have
had some success with it.
Well, I think it's fair to say, talking about the
Farsight Institute and Courtney Brown, that there
was, I would have to call it a huge scandal.
Yeah. And perhaps since we're talking about the
history of the field it should be addressed.
Yeah, it's kind of an unpleasant chapter.
So what happened was that Comet Hale-Bopp was coming into our solar system in 1997
and it was detected by, I guess Hale and Bop,
I don't know anything about the names… Astronomers.
And someone sent Courtney some doctored photographs
of the comet that seemed to show a companion
of some sort along with the comet which Courtney
Brown then had his professional remote viewers
remote view, people he'd trained in this SRV methodology.
They reported it was a giant alien spaceship
that was coming to Earth to deliver a message. He was
on Art Bell talking about this on Coast to Coast and there's lots of discussion
about it.
At some point Heaven's Gate, 39 people I think it was, committed suicide because
they wanted to get on the spaceship that was accompanying hale-Bopp.
It was a cult. And the
cult leaders picked up on this conversation that Courtney Brown had had and said, “Yes,
the aliens are coming for us and if we commit
suicide they will be able to transport us
in their UFO.”
And 39 people committed suicide. Yes.
Now, Courtney Brown’s belief about this thing wasn't the total cause of that.
I mean, I've since researched that a bit
and they probably would have done it anyway.
But that was kind of a catalyst in a way,
that at least appears to have been a kind of
a catalyst. It created a terrible cloud over the whole
field of remote viewing in terms of people's gullibility.
Yeah, and especially became a problem when they
discovered that the photographs were actually
fake, that there wasn't any such companion.
Then Art Bell actually was absolutely livid about this.
He kicked Courtney Brown off the air because
he first of all tried to hold his feet to
the fire and then said... You know, he kicked him
off the air and would not allow him to ever come
back again.
As far as I know I don't think Courtney's been on Coast to Coast since.
No, but he continues to write and research and
train people in remote viewing and do whatever
he can to repair his reputation from that terrible mistake.
But it does show one of the weaknesses of remote viewing, which is that people can
be misled.
Remote viewers can be influenced by the things they hear or learn about.
Oh absolutely. And one of the qualities if you intend to be
a serious remote viewer, one of the qualities
you have to have is you have to be very careful
about what you believe and what you don't believe.
Don't even necessarily believe the stuff you perceive because you can be wrong in a
remote viewing session too.
That's why Ingo always insisted that if you want to count it as real remote viewing you
have to be remote viewing, in principle,feedback-able targets.
In other words, targets that you can actually,
in principle at least, get feedback on.
So that is why when I do my training I only give my students real-world targets.
The reason is if you can't get feedback you can't see how well you did.
So you can't learn.
You need to have actually a concrete relationship
to the target so you can determine, “Oh right,
I got this right, I got that wrong.
Next time I'm going to not do that, I'm gonna do this.”
Courtney has continued to focus in
conspiracy and other worldly kinds of targets
and leading bleeding edge speculative kind of material.
A lot of people find that attractive and a lot of people are fascinated by that kind
of thing. So he does serve a certain sector of the population
out there who’s interested in remote viewing
of who killed JFK, or I don't think he's ever
done Bigfoot, but he might be tempted to do
something like that.
He set up an experiment that he hoped would show the existence of an actual multiverse,
you know, try and solve this physics question, a
cosmological question really about the multiverse.
He's trying to do those kinds of things.
He goes on these actually outward edged kind
of stuff, which although led to another XRV, sort of.
He had a, I guess disciple, Prudence Calabrese,
and she was on board. It's hard to tell
but I think she had something to do with the Hale-Bopp fiasco
but when it was all over with she blamed Courtney Brown for the whole thing. I think
she probably was also on board at the time.
But she formed her own methodology which she
called at different times… Transdimensional
Systems was her company and people usually refer to her methodology as that.
But she called it Knosomatics, K N O S O M A T I C S.
So Knosomatics, essentially from the Greek for knowledge, or at least one form.
Gnosis. Yeah, gnosis.
It was essentially SRV. So we have CRV, TRV,
SRV. Now we have this Knosomatics, which
is essentially SRV but with her own refinements added.
One of the things she did, and she thought
she was inventing it, she actually went back
to some of the original Ingo methodology thinking
that this idea was a better approach, and
it is, it is a better approach.
A lot of the really efficacious stuff from CRV has kind of been bred out of it as it's
come down stream through these different variations that people have come up with.
And so she sort of inadvertently reinvented the wheel in a way.
She has disappeared from the remote viewing world but there are some folks out there
who still practice it and there's some videos
online that she goes through and explains
what it is she does.
But that is yet another methodology there.
So, to go back up to the CRV there's actually more than one flavor of CRV.
I learned the Ingo methodology, I learned
directly from Ingo and Hal, and I try and approach
it exactly the way Ingo did.
Now, there's a couple of things I changed,
and unlike the rest of these guys I actually
admit when I change something, right. I tell
people because I want them to have full disclosure.
So one of them is that Ingo was absolutely
convinced that the autonomic nervous system played a
role in what we call ideograms, that kind of thing.
Well, we know now that that's not true because
the autonomic nervous system doesn't control
hand and arm movements, for example.
So I don't teach that anymore but I tell people about that when I teach my classes.
So, Lyn Buchanan teaches CRV, but he has taken the CRV methodology and put his own
brand on it.
He changed all the terminology so that, for
example in CRV, Ingo version, you have what's
called analytical overlay, which is mental noise is generated by your left brain.
Lynn now calls that “STRAY CAT.”
STRAY CAT.
Some kind of acronym, I don't recall how it breaks out but he calls it
STRAY CAT.
That's fine,
I don't care if you change the terminology, but it does change the system somewhat.
And then he's added some stuff to it that Ingo
didn't have like... Oh shoot, I can't think
right now. It’s where you get contaminated and polluted, you know... that's not the
right term.
Whatever, he’s added some stuff and his doctrine
on some elements are much different than how
Ingo used to teach it.
And again, in this case I'm not gonna tell you where that's better or worse.
I mean, the results tell that
and some of these folks have done some really
amazing stuff, and so it does work apparently.
Some
of his students have carried on with their version of his version of CRV.
Well, that seems to be the way it goes. At
this point it's fair to say that thousands of people have been trained.
Yes, particularly, I mean Dames, his videos and
all that stuff if you count that as training.
We haven't even talked about the Mobius group
which was sort of independent of the military
entirely. Yes. So yeah, I mean it's interesting. I kind of
see the... I don't want to call it evolution
because some of it isn’t evolutionary, right.
Some of it is actually devolutionary, the way CRV has been kind of parceled out into
all these different little packets.
Part of it as a function of ego. Part of it is ego, part of it is marketing. So
you need to differentiate yourself from other people so people will have a reason
to come to you instead of somebody else.
So they make their own mark, their own branding and that kind of thing.
In other words, you're competing against your former colleagues.
I am, yeah.
Although my sense is that there's a lot of camaraderie. Practically every serious
remote viewer has some connection with the International Remote Viewing Association,
I imagine.
Well, Joe doesn't, Joe McMoneagle doesn't have anything to do with this. And Dave
Morehouse doesn't.
Well, he’s the other CRVer, right.
He also teaches or taught, I'm not sure what his status is right now at CRV, but he
also added some things and took some things away.
So just because it says Controlled Remote Viewing doesn't necessarily mean it's an
Ingo style.
In other words, you might take several different
remote viewing courses that say they're teaching
CRV and they'll all be a bit different. Yeah. I've had students do that.
I've had students that are taking my classes
taking classes from Lynn and Dave and Ed.
I'm not sure about anybody else but there might be.
And then you get a certain category of people,
and I suppose I consider myself amongst them,
who started doing remote viewing and it worked
right away and never took any training at all.
Which brings us to another category I have which is GRV for Generic Remote Viewing.
This is the point I like to make often because you get these CRV Nazis, right.
You get people who think the whole world
revolves around CRV, Controlled Remote Viewing.
They think that's what everybody has done, always done, and always will do.
They don't realize there's a whole history of the remote viewing world before CRV was
developed in the early ‘80s where there were
remote viewers doing it however they did it.
Everybody
had their own different kind of style and approach that were doing
work every bit as good and often better
than what most of the CRVrs today are doing.
CRV is not a magic bullet.
It's a very effective way of helping someone who has not developed these
skills to develop them in a relatively quick period of time.
But there are people who do marvelous remote
viewing without ever even hearing the acronym CRV.
People need to realize that. But
I suppose the important thing to say about CRV goes back to your own experience.
It took you, you a person who never considered
yourself in the least bit psychic, and now you train.
Yeah. Well, Paul Smith what a pleasure to be with you.
I know we're going to have more conversations
while you're here in Albuquerque.
This has been an excellent overview of how the field has evolved up until this point.
Thank you for being with me.
Oh, you are welcome.
I appreciate it.
And thank you for being with us.
